questions.question: The most common cause of peripheral vascular disease is?
What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.explanation: The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittentclaudication.Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reducedblood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronicvascular occlusive disease.Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced andcramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest.A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in thedependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red andswollen(sunset foot sign).Buerger's test is done to assess the severity of peripheral vascular disease. In normal individuals,the elevation of the lower limb to a 90-degree angle does not produce any pallor but in affectedindividuals, even at an elevation of 20-degrees, pallor and venous guttering of the limb can beseen.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the lower limbs, onwalking a certain distance. He noticed that the pain subsides on resting. Which of thefollowing is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Pain is usually felt in the calf muscles
options.B: Muscle group affected is below the level of arterial disease
options.C: Distance at which pain occurs varies greatly from day to day
options.D: Worsened by anemia or heart failure

questions.explanation: The patient is likely experiencing intermittent claudication due to peripheral occlusive vasculardisease.1171Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reducedblood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronicvascular occlusive disease.The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient canwalk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudicationdistance. This distance varies only slightly from day-to-day. The muscle group affected is oneanatomical level below the arterial disease.Boyd's classificationClass 1 Pain on walking but pain decreases on continuation of walking.Class Il-Pain on walking, but continues to walk despite the pain.Class Ill - Pain forces the patient to stop walking.Class IV Pain at rest.-It is worsened by health conditions such as anemia and heart failure.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male who is a chronic smoker presented to the hospital with intermittentclaudication pain of both thigh and buttock region on walking about 500 m. Which of thefollowing is a likely diagnosis?1162

options.A: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
options.D: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. Classically,the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterialdisease.Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery.Aortoiliac disease affects the infrarenal aorta and iliac arteries.Management involves smoking cessation, lifestyle modifications, and treatment of underlyingdiabetes or hyperlipidemia if present.For claudication, cilostazol or pentoxyfilline is used. Cilostazol is superior to pentoxyfilline.Surgical options include aortoiliac bypass, aortobifemoral bypass, percutaneous transluminalangioplasty (PTA), which can be with or without stent placement, and thromboendarterectomy.Correlation of clinical findings to the Site of DiseaseAortoiliac obstructionIliac obstructionFemoropopliteal obstructionClaudication inbuttocks, thighs, and calvesBruit over the aortoiliac regionImpotence(Leriche's syndrome)Claudication ofthigh and calf,unilaterallyAbsence of femoral and distal pulses Bruit overiliac regionClaudication incalfFemoral pulse felt but distal pulses absent1172Correlation of clinical findings to the Site of DiseaseDistal obstructionAnkle pulses absentClaudication incalf and footFemoral and popliteal pulses palpable

questions.question: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by all except_
questions.explanation: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by rest pain and/or ulceration and gangrene. Intermittentclaudication progresses to rest pain in critical limb ischemia.Rest pain occurs with the limb at rest and is felt in the foot; it is exacerbated by lying down orelevation of the foot. Characteristically, the pain is worse at night and it may be lessened byhanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair. The pressure of clothes on the foot usuallymakes the pain worse.Ulceration occurs with severe arterial insufficiency and may present as painful erosion betweentoes or as shallow, non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the feet, on the shins, and especiallyaround the malleoli. The blackened mummified tissues of frank gangrene are unmistakable andsuperadded infection often makes the gangrene wet.

questions.question: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI)likely to be?
questions.explanation: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

questions.question: A 35-year-old chronic smoker presents with bluish discoloration of the toe along withintermittent claudication. Which of the following will be the next appropriate investigation inthis patient?
questions.explanation: Chronic smoker presenting with bluish discoloration of the toe along with intermittentclaudication is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease and duplex scanning will be the nextappropriate investigation.Duplex Scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode ultrasound to provide animage of the vessel. Most scanners now have color coding, which allows detailed visualization ofblood flow in a vessel. Different colors indicate changes in the direction and velocity of flow, withareas of high flow usually indicating stenotic lesions.Other options:Option A: CT Angiography (CTA) is more useful in the evaluation of visceral arterial disease (eg.mesenteric ischemia). It can be beneficial in peripheral artery diseases where a duplex scan showspoor images (aortoiliac segment involvement). CTA is not routinely recommended in peripheralartery disease because of concomitant renal dysfunction in these patients which can lead tocontrast-induced nephropathy.Option B: MR Angiography is time-consuming and expensive, hence not done as the nextinvestigation. It is contraindicated in patients with claustrophobia and metallic implants.1173Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive and expensiveprocedure compared to other investigations. The benefits of DSA are that it provides dynamicarterial flow information and can be combined with a definitive endovascular intervention whenindicated. DSA is indicated only when there is a discrepancy in diagnosis or intervention isplanned. Complications associated with DSA include bleeding, hematoma, false aneurysmformation, thrombosis, arterial dissection, distal embolisation, renal dysfunction, and allergicreaction.MRADSACTA

questions.question: 1163Which of the following is false regarding the investigation of peripheral arterial disease?

options.A: Duplex scanning is a non invasive technique
options.B: On doppler ultrasound a normal artery has a biphasic signal
options.C: DSA is now the standard technique used
options.D: Computed tomographic angiography is not used routinely to diagnose PAD

The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosisand monophasic in severe stenosis.Option A: Duplex scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-modeultrasound to provide an image of the vessel.Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique whereby theimages obtained are digitized by computer and the extraneous background (bone, soft tissues,etc.) is removed to provide clearer images.Option D: Computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and conventional catheter-basedangiography should not be used for routine diagnostic testing but are performed before potentialrevascularization. These tests define the anatomy that assists in planning for revascularizationprocedures.1174Triphasic signal2A. tibialis post

questions.question: A patient with right leg arterial stenosis is being taken up for angioplasty. Which one of thefollowing is incorrect about this procedure?

options.A: It is done for patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis
options.B: It gives best results for management of stenosis below the knee
options.C: Satisfactory dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram

questions.explanation: Angioplasty gives the best results for medium-sized vessels hence it is preferred for treating thevessels above the knee in peripheral arterial disease.Angioplasty is indicated in patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis.•Steps of angioplasty:Patients posted for angioplasty are given aspirin (325 mg) and clopidogrel (loading dose of300-600 mg).During the procedure, anticoagulation is achieved by administration of unfractionated heparin,enoxaparin, or bivalirudin (a direct thrombin inhibitor).• The femoral artery is punctured under local anesthetic, followed by insertion of a guidewire. Theguidewire is negotiated through the stenosis or occlusion under fluoroscopic control.• A balloon catheter is then inserted over the guidewire and positioned within the lesion. Theballoon is then inflated at high pressure for approximately 1 minute and deflated.• Once the angioplasty is done, dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram.1175HeartCoronary arterylocated on thesurface of the heartNarrowedPlaquearteryCoronaryarteryPlaqueCathebersClosed stentExpanded stentBalloonClosed stent aroundballoon catheterArtery cross-sectionStent widened arteryCompressed plaqueIncreasedblood flowStentCompressedplaqueWidenedartery

questions.question: Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?
questions.explanation: The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE),dacron, and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass.The GSV is the conduit of choice for arterial bypass grafts below the inguinal ligament.For bypass above the inguinal ligament, while both GSV and PTFE grafts have similar patencyrates in the first 2 years, the GSV is superior thereafter and hence preferred over PTFE or anyother grafts.The ipsilateral GSV is the conduit of choice for femoropopliteal bypass. When it is not available,contralateral GSV should be used. Other veins are preferred when both ipsilateral andcontralateral GSV is not available and they include a small saphenous vein, cephalic vein, andbasilic vein.Non-autogenous grafts are used for patients who lack a suitable venous conduit. The mostcommonly used prosthetic conduit is PTFE. Recent studies have shown that heparin-bondedPTFE is superior to compared to PTFE without heparin.

questions.question: A 52-year-old man presented with complaints of pain in the right leg right for a day. He has ahistory of recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements are falseregarding his condition?

options.A: Ischemia beyond 6 hrs is usually irreversible
options.B: Pain, pallor, pulselessness, and parasthesia/anesthesia are characteristic
options.C: Movement of the digits is not affected
options.D: Embolectomy and thrombolysis are treatment options1164

questions.explanation: The patient most likely has acute arterial occlusion and atrial fibrillation can predispose to emboliformation. In acute arterial occlusion, the movement of the digits will be affected and the limbwill be cold. Whereas, in venous occlusion, muscle function is not affected.The leg is often affected with:• Pain• Pallor1176•Paralysis• Loss of pulsation• Paraesthesia (or anesthesia).Embolic arterial occlusion is an emergency that requires immediate treatment. Ischaemia beyond6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss.The diagnosis can be made clinically in a patient who has no history of claudication and has asource of emboli, who suddenly develops severe pain or numbness of the limb, which becomescold and mottled.

questions.question: An elderly man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe pain andnumbness of the left lower limb. He has no previous history of any limb claudication. Thelimb appears to be cold and peripheral pulses are not palpable. What is the most appropriatenext step?

options.C: CT Angiogram to check for embolus
options.D: Thrombolysis with intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) infusion

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of sudden arterial occlusion. The immediate next step isto administer 5000 IU of heparin to prevent extension of clot.Management of sudden arterial occlusion:• Embolectomy with Fogarty's balloon catheter is the definitive treatment of choice.• Thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can be done in cases where there are noacute signs of limb ischemia as complete lysis of thrombus in tPA infusion is achieved within 24hours, however, it is cautiously used in the elderly due to risk of bleeding diathesis.• A CT angiogram is performed after the procedure to ensure that the flow to the distal leg hasbeen restored.Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and may result in limb loss.Complications of arterial revascularization•Compartment syndrome•Reperfusion syndrome•Ischaemic neuropathy••MyoglobinuriaRenal failureUsually, a prophylactic fasciotomy is done in patients undergoing revascularization surgery toprevent compartment syndrome.

questions.question: A 71-year-old man had an acute STEMI for which coronary stenting was performed. On thefollow-up visit, he reported pain over his toes and discoloration of both feet as shown in theimage. His creatinine was also elevated. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atheroembolism. It is also called cholesterol embolismor blue toe syndrome.Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, andcholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites.1177The typical presentation is a patient with ST-elevation myocardial infarction presenting withfeatures of limb ischemia (cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) followingan intraarterial procedure (angioplasty).Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis andgangrene may develop. Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sitesof emboli. Since the atheroemboli tend to lodge in the small vessels of the limbs and may notocclude the large vessels, distal pulses are usually palpable.Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as wellas stroke and renal insufficiency. Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals.Sharp syndrome, also known as mixed connective tissue disease, is an autoimmune condition withfeatures of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Clinical features include Raynaud'ssyndrome, polyarthritis, myositis, swollen hands, and fingers.

questions.question: DAILYROUNDS1165A patient with untreated severe peripheral arterial disease comes to the surgery OPD with aright leg as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Usually affects most distal part of a limb
options.B: It is a surgical emergency if crepitus is felt on palpation
options.C: Occurs when tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of blood stream
options.D: Amputation is not done if severe sepsis is present

questions.explanation: The patient is suffering from gangrene of the foot. If there is severe sepsis and if re-establishingblood supply is difficult(revascularization) then amputation is the preferred choice of treatment.Gangrene refers to death of macroscopic portions of tissue which turn black because of thebreakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide.It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis,embolus or arteritis).Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream. WetGangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may bepalpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms commonly in diabetic foot problems.

questions.question: A 51-year-old, diabetic patient presents with the following features during a village healthcamp. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?1166

options.A: Due to immunosuppression caused by elevated glucose levels
options.B: Repeated injury leads to Charcot's foot
options.C: Glycemic control and antibiotic therapy is first line managment
options.D: Sensory nerves are affected in the late stage of disease

questions.explanation: The image and clinical scenario are suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the foot. It is accompaniedby sensory loss in the early stage of the disease and motor involvement in the late stage.Diabetic gangrene is caused by a combination of three factors:• Ischemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction,• Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, which leads to trophic skin changes.Immunosuppression is caused by excess sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infectionDiabetic gangrene is accompanied by loss of sensation and reflexes which lead to repeated injury.There occurs an imbalance between the flexors and extensors of the foot which causes deformitiesknown as Charcot's foot (neuropathic joints).Initial treatment comprises strict glycemic control and antibiotic therapy. The gangrene is treatedby drainage of pus, debridement of dead tissue with local amputation of necrotic digits.1178

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncopeand cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practicesessions. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

options.A: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
options.B: Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
options.C: CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian stealsyndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of thesubclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in thevertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm ofthe affected side are found to be feeble.Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.Subclavian Steal SyndromeVertebralarteryTo right armBrachiocephalicarteryMAAorticarchOMARROWBasilar arteryRetrogradeflowTo left armStenosis of thesubclavianarteryW

questions.question: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome which of the following structure is affected?
questions.explanation: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome, the subclavian vein is affected.Compression of subclavian vein between anterior scalene, clavicle, and the first rib can produceaxillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. It results in severe upper extremity pain and swelling, thatis exaggerated by exercise.Activities such as throwing, swimming, and weightlifting can cause microtrauma of the venousintima that initiates thrombus formation.

questions.question: A 26-year-old male patient who came to the OPD with complaints of pain and numbness ofthe arm is diagnosed with thoracic outlet syndrome. Which nerve is involved in thiscondition?
questions.explanation: In thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) the lower two nerve roots of the brachial plexus, C8 and T1 aremost commonly involved and produce pain and paresthesia along the ulnar nerve distribution.1179

questions.question: A resident is trying to elicit symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome in a patient. He asks thepatient to keep both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and to open andclose the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. What is this test called?
questions.explanation: The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roostest (extended arm stress test).

questions.question: A young woman presents to the hospital with sudden discoloration of the hands. Which of thefollowing would suggest a diagnosis of acrocyanosis over Raynaud's phenomenon?
questions.explanation: In acrocyanosis, there is no pain or numbness. In Raynaud's phenomenon, there is pain andtingling sensation.Acrocyanosis is a chronic, benign vasoconstrictive disorder. It is due to arterial vasoconstrictionand secondary dilation of the capillaries and venules that results in persistent cyanosis of thehands and feet. It can be primary or secondary.Primary acrocyanosis is more common in females with an onset <30 years. Trophic skinchanges and ulcerations do not occur and examination reveals normal pulses.The disorder can be distinguished from Raynaud's phenomenon:• Because it is persistent and not episodic• There is no pain in acrocyanosis whereas in Raynaud's phenomenon there is pain and numbness• The discoloration extends proximally from the digits•Blanching does not occur

questions.question: A 24-year-old female nurse was on her way to the hospital for her early morning shift.Suddenly she started to notice pain in her fingers which were turning pale and numb afterwhich they turned blue. Which of the following statements are false regarding this condition?

options.A: Triggered by cold as well as stress
options.B: Calcium channel blockers are used for treatment
options.C: Mainstay of treatment includes avoidance of triggers
options.D: Is not associated with autoimmune diseases

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Raynaud's phenomenon. Secondary causes ofRaynaud's phenomenon are seen in association with autoimmune diseases such as scleroderma,systemic lupus erythematosus etc.Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by triphasic color response of the fingers or toes:••Digital blanching or pallor• Cyanosis• Rubor1180Digitalarteriessupplyblood tofingers-NormalbloodflowDigitalarteryAdarycross-sectionConstricteddigitalarteriesConstricted digital arteriesblock blood to fingertips,causing discolorationArterycross-sectionBloodflowblockedConstricteddigital arteryPrimary Raynaud's phenomenon (Raynaud's disease)Idiopathic and more commonWomen are more commonlyaffectedAge of presentation is betweeIn 20 to 40 yearsEpisodicAffects both hands and feetSecondary Raynaud's phenomenonSecondary to other conditions (autoimmune diseases, vibration injury)No gender predispositionPresent later in lifeAffects either both hands orboth feet

questions.question: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Buerger's disease?
questions.explanation: Statements 1 and 3 are false. In thromboangitis obliterans, there is normal brachial and poplitealpulses but reduced or absent radial, ulnar, and/or tibial pulses. It is most common in malesmokers, usually under the age of 30 years.Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorderinvolving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities.The clinical features include a triad of:•Claudication of the affected extremity•Raynaud's phenomenon•Migratory superficial vein thrombophlebitisPatients frequently have rest pain, ulceration, and digital gangrene.1181

questions.question: A 34-year-old male construction worker presents with exertional pain and darkening of theskin in both forearms and hands as shown in the image. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes perday and has no comorbidities On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial andulnar pulses are feeble. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmentallesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chanceof success?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specifictreatment except abstinence from tobacco. Key findings in this patient is age < 40 years,smoker, and involvement of upper extremity.Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship tocigarette smoking in patients with this disorder. There is no specific treatment except abstentionfrom tobacco.MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distalvessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion.The prognosis is poor in individuals who continue to smoke.Surgical revascularization is not possible due to extensive vascular inflammation and damage.Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful. If the condition worsens, amputation may berequired.

questions.question: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with cramping pain in the buttocks and erectiledysfunction for the past 6 months. He has no history of bladder dysfunction or fecalincontinence. Examination revealed absent femoral pulses and normal sensory and motorsystem. How will you surgically manage this patient?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome. The treatment of choice here isaortobifemoral grafting.Leriche syndrome is due to occlusion at the aortic bifurcation and is characterized by• Buttock claudication•Impotence•• Absence of femoral pulse.•No sensory or motor deficit• Normal reflexesAtherosclerosis is the most common cause of Leriche syndrome.Differential diagnosis includes• Abdominal dissection• Spinal canal stenosis•Spinal disc herniationAortofemoral grafting is done in unilateral iliac vessel occlusion.Iliofemoral grafting is done for unilateral occlusion of distal common iliac or external iliac artery.Illiopopliteal grafting is done for femoral artery occlusion.1182Intermittent claudicationPain after walking a certain distancePain quickly relieved on resting.Neurogenic claudicationPain after walking or standingfor some timePain relieved on flexionosteoarthritisMaximum pain on the first step.Pain relieved on resting.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication for a carotid endarterectomy?
questions.explanation: Dysphonia is not an indication for carotid endarterectomy. Carotid endarterectomy is done incarotid artery stenosis.Indications of carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients.CT angiography showing 70% or more stenosis and•• Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness• Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia•Arm/leg paralysis or paresthesia• Hemianopia• Dysphasia1183
